case_name: Trustees of Shri Chandre Prabhuji Jain Temple v. Manorama

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1701 of 1967 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated December 1, 1961 of the Madras High Court in O.S.A. No. 17 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1701 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 1, 1961 of the Madras High Court in O.S.A. No. 17 of 1957.

facts.text: Gopalakrishna Raju died in Madras on or about November 13, 1941, leaving behind his widow Manorama, one minor son and two minor daughters.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MATHEW, J.--One Gopalakrishna Raju  hereinafter called Raju died in Madras on or about November 13, 1941, leaving behind him his window Manorama, one minor son and two minor daughters.

facts.text: Raju executed a will on March 25, 1941 appointing Manorama as executor and guardian of minor son and daughters, bequeathing all properties to minor son with directions for maintenance and marriage of daughters.

anchor.surface_text: On March 25, 1941, Raju had executed a will whereby he appointed Manorama the executor of the will and the guardian of his-minor son and daughters and bequeather a.1 his properties to the minor son with directions as regards the maintenance and marriage of his daughters.

facts.text: On June 7, 1948, Manorama mortgaged certain properties to raise Rs. 7,000 for marriage expenses of her elder daughter.

anchor.surface_text: On June 7, 1948, Manorama mortgaged certain properties to raise a loan of Rs. 7,000/- for the purpose of meeting the marriage expenses of her elder daughter.

facts.text: Manorama filed application under sections 7 and 10 of Guardians and Wards Act on August 26, 1948 before Madras High Court to appoint her as guardian, without disclosing the will, claiming half ownership of two houses and minor son the other half.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, she filed an application under sections 7 and 10 of the Guardians and Wards Act. 1890, hereinafter called the Act on August 26, 1948, before the High Court of Madras to appoint her as the guardian of her minor children. In that petition she did number disclose that Raju died after executing a will, but said that Raju died leaving two houses Nos. 18 and 18A in Egmore, Madras and that she was the owner of one half of the houses and that her minor son was the owner of the other half.

facts.text: On September 9, 1948, Madras High Court appointed Manorama as guardian of person and property of minor son and daughters and granted permission to raise Rs. 7,000 loan by mortgaging two houses.

anchor.surface_text: On September 9, 1948, the Court passed an order appointing Manorma as the guardian of the person and property of the minor son and daughter and, by another order, granted her permission to raise a loan of Rs. 7,000/- by mortgaging the two houses.

facts.text: On September 24, 1948, Manorama borrowed Rs. 7,000 by mortgaging the two houses based on court orders.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of these orders, she borrowed a sum of Rs. 7,000/- on September 24, 1948, by mortgaging the two houses.

facts.text: On January 19, 1950, Manorama applied to High Court for permission to raise Rs. 40,000 loan on security of two houses.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, she filed another application on January 19, 1950, seeking permission of the High Court to raise a loan of Rs,40,000/- on the security of the two houses.

facts.text: On January 23, 1950, High Court allowed Rs. 30,000 loan under s.29 of the Act on security of two houses belonging to the minor.

anchor.surface_text: On January 23, 1.950, the application was allowed under s. 29 of the Act permitting her to raise a loan of Rs. 30,000/- on the security of the two houses belonging to the minor.

facts.text: On March 4, 1950, Manorama borrowed Rs. 30,000 from trustees of Shri Chandre Prabhuji Jain Temple (appellants) by mortgaging two houses.

anchor.surface_text: On the strength of this order, Manorama borrowed on March 4, 1950, a sum of Rs. 30,000/- from the trustees of Shri Chandre Prabhuji Jain Temple, the appellants before this Court, by executing a mortgage of the two houses.

facts.text: On April 24, 1950, Manorama applied for further Rs. 15,000 loan on two houses, sanctioned for Rs. 10,000.

anchor.surface_text: She again applied on April 24, 1950, to the Court for raising a further loan of Rs. 15,000/- on the security of these two houses but sanction was accorded to raise a loan of only Rs. 1.0.000/

facts.text: On May 31, 1950, Manorama borrowed Rs. 10,000 from appellants by mortgaging same properties.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of this order she borrowed a further sum of Rs. 1,000/from the appellants by executing a mortgage on May 31, 1950, of the same properties.

facts.text: Manorama applied to sell one house to discharge amounts due to appellants, permission granted, sold to Indian Bank for Rs. 41,500.

anchor.surface_text: Manorama filed yet another application praying for permission to sell one of the houses with a view to enable her to discharge the amount due to the appellants under the two mortgages. The permission was granted and the Indian Bank Limited purchased one of the house properties for a sum of Rs. 41.500/-

facts.text: Indian Bank learned of Raju's will after sale, applied to set aside sale, which was done.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear that subsequent to the execution of the sale, the bank came to know that Raju had executed a will. So the bank applied to the High Court to have the sale set aside. This was done.

facts.text: Upon notice of will, Krishnaswami Nayudu J. directed Administrator-General to take possession of Raju's estate and apply for Letters of Administration.

anchor.surface_text: When the existence of the will, executed by Raju was brought to the numberice of the Court, Krishnaswami Nayudu, J. directed the Administrator-General to take immediate possession of the estate of Raju and to apply for Letters of Administration.

facts.text: Administrator-General obtained Letters of Administration, took possession, sold one house for Rs. 39,200 to Indian Bank with court sanction, retains proceeds.

anchor.surface_text: The Administrator-General obtained Letters of Administration and took possession of the estate. In the companyrse of the, administration, the Administrator-General, after obtaining the sanction of the Court put up for sale one of the houses in question. The Indian Bank purchased it for, Rs. 39,200/-. The sale proceeds are being retained by the Administrator-General.

facts.text: Appellants filed suit on original side of High Court to recover money due under two mortgages executed by Manorama as guardian.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed the suit on the original side of the High Court out of which this appeal arises, to recover the money due under the two mortgages executed in favour of the appellants by Manorama as guardian.

facts.text: Respondents contended Manorama had no authority to execute mortgages, obtained sanctions by fraud on court, appellants did not act with due care.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, namely, the Administrator-General and the minor son, companytended that Manorama had numberauthority to execute the mortgages and that she obtained the sanctions to execute the mortgages by practising fraud upon the companyrt. They also companytended that the appellants had number acted with due care, that the sanctions to mortgage given by the companyrt were only prima facie evidence that the transactions were beneficial to the minors but that they would number cure any inherent defect that existed in the transactions, that the enquiry companyducted by a companyrt in granting sanction was of a summary character, and that as the existence of the will has number been brought to the numberice of the companyrt, the sanctions to raise the loans were invalid and did number bind the minor.

facts.text: Balakrishna Ayyar J. held Manorama suppressed will deliberately (fraud), orders voidable, appellants not parties to fraud, entitled to recover from mortgaged properties, passed preliminary decree.

anchor.surface_text: Balakrishna Ayyar, J. who tried the suit held that Manorama deliberately suppressed the execution of the will by Raju and therefore, the orders authorizing her to raise the amounts by mortgaging the properties of the 2nd respondent were obtained by fraud. The learned Judge, however, held that since the orders were only voidable and as .the appellants were number parties to the fraud and as they were number required to go behind the orders, the appellants were entitled to recover the amount from the properties mortgaged and passed a preliminary decree.

facts.text: Full Bench of Madras High Court held orders under s.31/32 not conclusive proof, mortgages enforceable only against one half of properties, passed decree accordingly.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decree the respondents appealed and the appeal was referred to a Full Bench... The companyrt therefore, passed a decree for recovery of the amounts from one-half of the properties mortgaged. It is against this decree that this appeal by certificate- has been preferred.

facts.text: Supreme Court held orders of sanction invalid due to non-disclosure of will and restrictions, but voidable; appellants entitled to decree against sale proceeds and entire interest in other property with restitution.

anchor.surface_text: We pass a decree against the respondent-defendants directing them to pay the appellants the principal amount due under the two mortgages together with 6 per cent interest from June 1, 1950 on the principal amount up to the date of payment or realization. The amount decreed will be a charge on the sale proceeds of one of the properties which are being retained by the Administrator-General and, on the entire interest in the other property under the mortgages. The decree of the High Court is set aside and a decree in terms as aforesaid is passed.
an application under sections 7 and 10 of the Guardians and Wards Act. 1890, hereinafter called the Act on August 26, 1948, before the High Court of Madras

holdings.text: The orders appointing Manorama as guardian and sanctioning the mortgages authorized mortgage of the entire properties of the minor, not limited to one-half interest.

anchor.surface_text: The court appointed Manorama as guardian of the properties of the minor. The order does not show that she was appointed guardian in respect of the one half interest in the properties. A person looking into the order could not have found any limitation in it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order unambiguously appoints guardian of properties without limitation; statements in petition do not restrict scope; measured by order text itself.

holdings.text: No person is expected to go behind an unambiguous court order appointing guardian or sanctioning alienation.

anchor.surface_text: A person looking into the order could not have found any limitation in it. A purchaser of the properties of minor could not be expected to go behind the order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy protects reliance on court orders; no duty to investigate beyond face.

holdings.text: Section 28 requires court to be apprised of will and restrictions, and to pass written order permitting disposition notwithstanding restrictions; non-compliance invalidates sanction.

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 of the Act provides Where a guardian has been appointed by will or other instrument, his power to mortgage or charge, or transfer by sale, gift, exchange or otherwise, immovable property belonging to his ward

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.28; salutary principle for parental jurisdiction; no application or disclosure here.

holdings.text: Section 29 inapplicable where guardian appointed by will; court cannot grant permission under s.29 or s.31(2) for such guardian to mortgage immovable property.

anchor.surface_text: Section 29 says that where a person other than a Collector or than a guardian appointed by will or other instrument, has been appointed or declared by the court to be guardian of the property of a ward,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual exclusion in s.29 for will-appointed guardians.

holdings.text: Principle of s.28 binds High Court exercising inherent jurisdiction under s.3 GWA and Letters Patent.

anchor.surface_text: It does not follow from these rulings that the principle underlying S. 28 of the Act should not bind the High Court even while exercising its inherent powers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction; s.3 saves powers but s.28 principle of disclosure and discretion remains salutary.

holdings.text: Orders obtained by fraud (deliberate suppression of will) and non-compliance with ss.28/29, rendering them invalid.

anchor.surface_text: Balakrishna Ayyar, J. who tried the suit held that Manorama deliberately suppressed the execution of the will by Raju and therefore, the orders authorizing her to raise the amounts by mortgaging the properties

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts trial judge finding of deliberate fraud; plus statutory non-compliance.

holdings.text: Respondents entitled to challenge validity of sanction orders in appeal where appellants seek enhanced relief, despite no cross-appeal (O.41 r.33 CPC).

anchor.surface_text: But we think that there is no reason why they should not be allowed to urge the plea that the order of sanction were invalid when the appellants want not only to maintain the decree passed by the High Court but also to get a decree charging the entire Properties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellate power to do justice; respondents defend against further claim without imperiling existing decree.

holdings.text: Alienations in contravention of ss.28 or 29 are voidable, not void (per s.30).

anchor.surface_text: A disposal of property in contravention of the provisions of s. 28 or s. 29 is only voidable see s. 30 .

holdings.text: Restitution of benefits received is required as condition for avoiding voidable alienations under ss.28/29.

anchor.surface_text: Order 41, rule 33 of the Civil Procedure Code clothes the appellate court with the power to pass any decree or order which the trial court ought to have passed or made and to pass or make such further or other decree or order as the justice of the case may require.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Justice requires balancing; High Court precedents followed; appellants bona fide.

holdings.text: No opinion expressed on whether order under s.31(2) is conclusive proof of necessity/benefit.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, we do not think it necessary to express any opinion on the correctness or otherwise of the view of the High Court on the nature and effect of an order passed under S. 31 (2).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary for decision as resolved on other grounds.

holdings.text: Decree passed charging mortgage amount on sale proceeds retained by Administrator-General and entire interest in remaining property, with interest.

anchor.surface_text: We pass a decree against the respondent-defendants directing them to pay the appellants the principal amount due under the two mortgages together with 6 per cent interest from June 1, 1950 on the principal amount up to the date of payment or realization.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies above holdings; restitution via charge on full interest.

anchor.surface_text: He cited In re Mahadev Krishna Rupji 1 and The Raja of Vizianagaram v. The Secretary of State for India in Council 2 and said that the High Court of Madras had inherent jurisdiction to appoint a guardian and determine his powers untrammeled by the pro. visions of the Act. In the first of the cases above referred to, it was held by the Bombay High Court that though the Act does number sanction ,he Appointment of a guardian in respect of undivided share of a minor in a joint Hindu Family, the High Court of Bombay had inherent power to appoint a guardian.

precedents.cited_proposition: High Court has inherent power to appoint a guardian in respect of undivided share of a minor in joint family property though the Act does not sanction it
precedents.cited_holding: the High Court of Bombay had inherent power to appoint a guardian

precedents.citation: The Raja of Vizianagaram v. The Secretary of State for India in Council 2

anchor.surface_text: He cited In re Mahadev Krishna Rupji 1 and The Raja of Vizianagaram v. The Secretary of State for India in Council 2 and said that the High Court of Madras had inherent jurisdiction to appoint a guardian and determine his powers untrammeled by the pro. visions of the Act. In the first of the cases above referred to, it was held by the Bombay High Court that though the Act does number sanction ,he Appointment of a guardian in respect of undivided share of a minor in a joint Hindu Family, the High Court of Bombay had inherent power to appoint a guardian. In the latter case, the Madras High Court hold that the High Court has, under clause 17 of the Letters Patent, 1865, jurisdiction in regard to minors

precedents.case_name: Raja of Vizianagaram v. Secretary of State for India in Council
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court has jurisdiction under Letters Patent over minors not of British birth resident outside presidency town unaffected by the Act
precedents.cited_holding: the High Court has, under clause 17 of the Letters Patent, 1865, jurisdiction in regard to minors, though number of British birth, resident outside the limits of the Presidency town and its jurisdiction to act under that clause is number affected by the Act

precedents.citation: In the matter of Sirsh Chander Singh and Others 3

anchor.surface_text: In the matter of Sirsh Chander Singh and Others 3 the companyrt said that the question whether a person is appointed guardian of the person of the minor alone but of his property also must be determined on a perusal of the entire document appointing him. if powers of managing the properties of the minor are vested in a guardian and express restrictions are placed on his powers of alienation in the companyrse of the management, that is an indication that the appointment is as guardian of the property also.

precedents.cited_proposition: Whether a person is guardian of person or property determined by perusal of entire document; management powers and alienation restrictions indicate guardian of property
precedents.cited_holding: the question whether a person is appointed guardian of the person of the minor alone but of his property also must be determined on a perusal of the entire document appointing him

precedents.citation: The Management of Itakhoolic Tea Estate v. its workmen, 1

anchor.surface_text: In The Management of Itakhoolic Tea Estate v. its workmen, 1 the question whether in such circumstances, a respondent who has number appealed from the decree can be allowed to urge such a plea in answer to a claim ,by an appellant for a further decree although the plea might imperil the decree already obtained was left undecided.

precedents.case_name: Management of Itakhoolie Tea Estate v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Whether respondent without appeal can urge plea imperilling decree in response to appellant's claim for more relief

anchor.surface_text: But the Full Bench decision of the Madras High Court in Venkata Rao v. Satyanarayanamurthy 2 has held that it is open to a respondent who had number filed cross-objection with respect to the portion of the decree which had gone against him to urge in opposition to the appeal of the plaintiff, a companytention which if accepted by the trial companyrt would have necessitated the total dismissal of the suit but that the decree in so for as it was against him would stand.

precedents.cited_proposition: Respondent without cross-objection can urge contention against appellant's appeal that would dismiss suit, supporting decree in his favour
precedents.cited_holding: it is open to a respondent who had number filed cross-objection ... to urge in opposition to the appeal of the plaintiff, a companytention which if accepted ... would have necessitated the total dismissal of the suit but that the decree in so for as it was against him would stand
